concept.title: Tutorials
concept.shortdesc: Tutorials, like scenarios, should introduce the users to product functionality in terms of a real-life task.

conbody.p: Author tutorials as a compound document, with a main task topic that can contain a series of task and concept children. The parent task should start with an overview that tells users what they should expect to learn, and the last child should be a summary of what the tutorial has covered. You can chain tutorials together to show how the product is used to accomplish larger, end-to-end goals, or pick smaller specific tutorials that demonstrate selected pieces of functionality that require extra introduction, because the subject area is new or complicated.

Tutorials, like scenarios and samples, can be input for the task analysis that produces your task list. Tutorials can have a close relationship with samples, either modifying a shipped sample to demonstrate specific functionality, or showing how a particular sample was created. By using a sample as a starting point, you can skip introductory or repetitive instructions and concentrate on the tasks that require explanation. By using a sample as an ending point, you can give users something to compare their own results with, to validate their success or help troubleshoot any problems they encountered.
